title: Meghan Markle secretly visited the site where a teenage girl was murdered in South Africa as a 'personal gesture'
text:
Meghan Markle made a private trip to visit the site where a student was raped and murdered in South Africa, where she tied a ribbon "to pay her respects."

Buckingham Palace confirmed the visit after media reports, and said that she wanted to "show solidarity with those who have taken a stand against gender-based violence and femicide."

The murder of 19-year-old Uyinene Mrwetyana, 19 sparked outrage and protests across South Africa. The palace said her death is "seen as a critical point in the future of women's rights in South Africa."

The palace said that Markle also spoke with Mrwetyana's mother and has taken other private trips "to deepen her understanding of the current situation and continue to advocate for the rights of women and girls."

Meghan Markle privately visited the site where a teenaged girl was murdered in South Africa as a "personal gesture," leaving a yellow ribbon to "to pay her respects" and speaking with her mother.

Markle visited the site where 19-year-old Uyinene Mrwetyana, a student at the University of Cape Town, was raped and murdered in August.

The trip was done privately earlier this week, during Meghan and Prince Harry's royal tour with their son, Archie. British newspaper The Sun reported her visit on Friday, detailing that she wrote a message in the local Xhosa language that said: "We stand together in this situation. Harry & Meghan 26th September 2019."

Buckingham Palace then confirmed the visit to CNN, saying that Meghan had "closely followed the tragic story" and wanted to visit privately as a "personal gesture."

Sussex Royal, the official Instagram account for Meghan and Harry, shared an image of Meghan at the site on Saturday, with a statement: "The Duchess of Sussex has tied a ribbon at the site where 19-year-old Cape Town student Uyinene Mrwetyana was murdered last month, to pay her respects and to show solidarity with those who have taken a stand against gender-based violence and femicide."

Read more: Meghan Markle was filmed dancing with Cape Town locals, and Prince Harry awkwardly tried to join in

Mrwetyana's death sparked widespread outrage and protests in South Africa, drawing attention to the high number of women killed in the country.

"The Duke and Duchess had been following what had happened from afar and were both eager to learn more when they arrived in South Africa. The Duchess spoke to the mother of Uyinene this week to relay their condolences," the statement said. "Uyinene's death has mobilized people across South Africa in the fight against gender based violence, and is seen as a critical point in the future of women's rights in South Africa."

The statement also confirmed that Markle has made other private visits, outside of the formal tour schedule: "The Duchess has taken private visits and meetings over the last two days to deepen her understanding of the current situation and continue to advocate for the rights of women and girls."

Read more: Here's how Meghan Markle and Prince Harry's first family royal tour is different from Prince William and Kate Middleton's

Markle has long identified as a feminist and made clear that women's rights would be a focus for her as she entered the royal family.

She has worked with women's' groups in London and recently designed a collection that aids a charity that helps unemployed and vulnerable women get back into the workplace.

"Visiting the site of this tragic death and being able to recognize Uyinene, and all women and girls affected by [Gender-Based Violence] (specifically in South Africa, but also throughout the world) was personally important to The Duchess," the Sussex Royal statement said.

Local students told The Sun that Meghan's visit "means so much" and that they appreciated her awareness of gender-based violence in South Africa.

"It means a lot that she came to our community and paid tribute without showing off without any publicity. She was being genuine," one 17-year-old student, Shaima Khan, who attends a nearby school, told the outlet.
